text: MATERIAL OF CHANGES

On October 1, 2010, the organization name for the Division Counsel (Large and Mid-Size Business) became the Division Counsel (Large Business and International). CCDM subsections 32.4.3.1, 32.4.3.2.1, 32.4.3.3, 32.4.3.3.1, 32.4.3.3.2, 32.4.3.3.3, and 32.4.3.4 were revised accordingly.
Table of

) The Large Business and International Division (LB&I) developed the Industry Issue Resolution (IIR) Program to work with business taxpayers, industry ciations, taxpayer representatives, and other interested parties to identify frequently disputed tax issues common to a significant number of business taxpayers and to resolve those issues through published or administrative guidance. Resolving issues through prefiling guidance rather than post-filing examination is a goal of both the Service and the Office of Chief Counsel. (
) The Service announced the Industry Issue Resolution Pilot Program in
C.B.

The objective of the pilot program was to and evaluate a procedure to resolve frequently disputed tax issues that are common to a significant number of large or mid-size business taxpayers through prefiling guidance rather than post-filing examination. After the pilot program, the Service announced in Notice
I.R.B.
, that the IIR Program would be made permanent. (
) Notice

expanded the IIR Program to identify and resolve frequently disputed issues common to any size business taxpayers and to address tunities to reduce burden for all business taxpayers. LB&I and the Small Business and Self-Employed Division (SB/SE) share operational for the IIR Program. (
) Revenue Procedure
I.R.B.

, sets forth the procedures business taxpayers, industry associations, and other interested parties to submit issues for consideration under the IIR program. The program was modified to allow issues to be proposed on a continuous basis and to for selections for the IIR program to be made at least semi-annually. (
) This section provides instructions regarding the coordination within Counsel issues proposed for inclusion in the Industry Issue Resolution Program. (

) Generally, the primary method of soliciting issues for the IIR program was by means of Notices. Because submissions may now be made at any time, the Potential Service may issue periodic News Releases concerning the IIR program will include an invitation for submission of proposed issues. (
) The issues most appropriate for inclusion in the IIR Program will have two or more of the following characteristics: for (cid:
) The proper tax treatment of a common factual situation is uncertain (cid:
) The uncertainty results in frequent, and often repetitive, examinations of same issue (cid:
) The uncertainty results in taxpayer burden (cid:
) The issue is significant and impacts a large number of taxpayers, either within an industry or across industry lines (cid:
) The issue requires extensive factual development, and an understanding industry practices and views concerning the issue would assist the in determining the proper tax treatment (
) The following issues are not suitable: (cid:
) Issues that are unique to one or a small number of taxpayers (cid:
) Issues that are primarily under the jurisdiction of Operating Divisions of Service other than the LB&I and SB/SE Divisions (

) Issues that involve transactions that lack a bona fide business purpose, or transactions with a significant purpose of improperly reducing or avoiding federal taxes (cid:
) Issues that involve transfer pricing or international tax treaties (

) The IIR Program is intended to engage business taxpayers, industry associa- tions, and other interested parties in the guidance process. Because other Issues avenues are available for Service personnel to suggest issues that need guidance, a proposal for the IIR Program from an employee, in general, will considered only if the proposal is adopted and sponsored by a business taxpayer, industry association, or other interested party. (

) An issue submitted for consideration under the IIR Program is not required to be submitted in a particular format. The submission should, however, include an issue statement, a description of why the issue is appropriate for the IIR Program, an explanation of the need for guidance, the estimated number of taxpayers affected by the issue, and the name and telephone number of a person to contact if additional information is needed. The submission may include a recommendation as to how the issue may be resolved. All submis- sions are made available for public inspection and copying in their entirety; therefore, the submission should not include confidential, taxpayer-specific in- formation. (

) Submission of issues for consideration under the IIR program will be directed to the LB&I Office of Pre-Filing and Technical Services. That office will a package (recommendation package) consisting of the information contained in the submission package and a check sheet for recommendations as to inclusion of an issue in the IIR Program. That office will forward the dation package to all functions from whom input is appropriate, including Counsel. (

) The recommendation package directed to Counsel will be sent to LB&I Counsel to the attention of the Special Counsel (Pre-filing and Guidance). Special Counsel (Pre-filing and Guidance) will forward the recommendation package, with any additional background material to the Technical Services Section of the Office of Associate Chief Counsel (PA) for assignment and the due date for a response from the Associate office with jurisdiction over the issue. The Special Counsel (Pre-filing and Guidance) will also advise all LB&I Area Counsel of the IIR issues that have been submitted through the Special Counsel located at the Division Counsel (LB&I) headquarters office. (

) To enable LB&I and SB/SE to timely consider the IIR issues submitted, the Associate Offices will review the recommendation packages and, within the time frame established for response, advise the Special Counsel (Pre-filing Guidance) or, if otherwise indicated, the Office of Pre-Filing and Technical Services, as to the appropriateness of the issue for possible inclusion in the IIR Program.
32.4 Special Pre-Filing Agreement Programs

The submission should, however, include an issue statement, a description of why the issue is appropriate for the IIR Program, an explanation of the need for guidance, the estimated number of taxpayers affected by the issue, and the name and telephone number of a person to contact if additional information is needed. ) LB&I and SB/SE will, first independently and then cooperatively, review the submissions to determine the order of priority that those functions believe issues should be considered and recommended for possible inclusion in the of IIR program and on the Guidance Priority List or a periodic update of that LB&I and SB/SE Division Counsel will assist in the review and prioritization process. (

) Issues selected for the IIR program will be included on the Guidance List or the periodic update of that list. However, a recommendation by LB&I Issues SB/SE does not guarantee that the issue will be selected either as an IIR Priority project or for inclusion on the Guidance Priority List or a periodic update of list. In deciding whether to select issues recommended by LB&I and SB/SE under the IIR Program for inclusion on the Guidance Priority List, the Office Chief Counsel and the Treasury Department will consider, among other recommendations from other sources and whether the requested guidance under the IIR Program promotes sound tax administration. Projects for the IIR Program may either be included on the Guidance Priority List for upcoming year or on a quarterly update to the list during the year. (

) LB&I and SB/SE are responsible for informing the parties who submitted issues that their issues were not selected for the IIR Program. When alternative methods of addressing the issue will be suggested and pursued. Issues (

) The Service, Treasury, and Chief Counsel will staff each project that is included in the IIR Program with a team (the IIR team). The team is and sible for gathering facts; meeting with taxpayers, industry associations, and of other interested parties; analyzing relevant information; and proposing a Counsel lution for the issue. IIR team members will include appropriate personnel LB&I and SB/SE, the Office of the Associate Chief Counsel with subject expertise with respect to the issue, Appeals, and Treasury. Typically, the Industry Counsel for the industry or issue to which the IIR pertains will be a member of the team. Other personnel, as needed, may be team members. some circumstance, the Service may find it necessary to hire outside (

) The Associate Chief Counsel representative on the IIR team will serve as subject matter expert and the primary drafter of any proposed guidance. preparation and issuance of the published guidance under the IIR Program the sole responsibility of the Office of Associate Chief Counsel. (
) Activities and duties of team members include: (cid:
) Participate in work team and industry orientations (cid:
) Assist in creating IIR work plan (cid:
) Provide technical expertise (cid:
) Discuss industry’s proposal for resolution (cid:
) Seek and evaluate facts and legal positions on the issue (cid:
) Consult with audit teams dealing with the issue (cid:
) Ensure that Counsel management stays informed during the project

The Associate Chief Counsel representative on the IIR team will serve as the subject matter expert and the primary drafter of any proposed guidance. The preparation and issuance of the published guidance under the IIR Program is the sole responsibility of the Office of Associate Chief Counsel.
32.4 Special Pre-Filing Agreement Programs

) All procedures applicable for published guidance projects on the Guidance Priority List are equally applicable to IIR projects included on the Guidance and Approval Priority List. The representative of the Office of Associate Chief Counsel is re- for Published sponsible for the clearance and approval process for IIR published guidance projects. Briefings on proposed guidance will include, whenever feasible, all IIR team members.
